column3: This vocabulary specifies how an instant of time can be represented (derived from Astropy Time.FORMATS: https://docs.astropy.org/en/stable/time/index.html#time-format).
Besselian Epoch year as  decimal value
column4: Besselian Epoch year as decimal value(s) like 1950.0. For information about this epoch format, see: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epoch_(astronomy)#Besselian_years.(0)

column3: Besselian Epoch year as a string
column4: Besselian Epoch year as string value(s) like ‘B1950.0’. For information about this epoch format, see: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epoch_(astronomy)#Besselian_years.(0)
Seconds from 1998-01-01 00:00:00 TT. For example, 63072064.184 is midnight on January 1, 2000.
Time as a decimal year, with integer values corresponding to midnight of the first day of each year. The fractional part represents the exact fraction of the year,
Seconds from 1980-01-06 00:00:00 UTC. For example, 630720013.0 is midnight on January 1, 2000.
Format “YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS.sss…”. For example, 2000-01-01 00:00:00.000 is midnight on January 1, 2000.

column3: ISO 8601 compliant date-time with a T as separator
column4: Format “YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS.sss…”. This is the same as TimeISO except for a “T” instead of space between the date and time.
This represents the number of days since the beginning of the Julian Period. For example, 2451544.5 in JD is midnight on January 1, 2000.

column3: Julian epoch year as decimal value
column4: Julian epoch year as decimal value(s) like 2000.0. This format is based the Julian year which is exactly 365.25 days/year and a day is exactly 86400 SI seconds.

column3: Julian Epoch year as string value
column4: Julian Epoch year as string value like ‘J2000.0’.
This represents the number of days since midnight on November 17, 1858. For example, 51544.0 in MJD is midnight on January 1, 2000.
Unix time (UTC): seconds from 1970-01-01 00:00:00 UTC, ignoring leap seconds. For example, 946684800.0 in Unix time is midnight on January 1, 2000.

SI seconds elapsed since 1970-01-01 00:00:00 TAI. This will generally differ from standard (UTC) Unix time by the cumulative integral number of leap seconds introduced into UTC since 1972-01-01 UTC plus the initial offset of 10 seconds at that date.
As “YYYY:DOY:HH:MM:SS.sss…”. The day-of-year (DOY) goes from 001 to 365 (366 in leap years). For example, 2000:001:00:00:00.000 is midnight on January 1, 2000.
